claim.text: Foundation models possess a latent ability to adaptively gather information in interactive environments, both text-based and embodied, opening exciting avenues for research and application.
claim.exact_quote: These findings suggest that foundation models possess a latent ability to adaptively gather information in interactive environments, both text-based and embodied, opening exciting avenues for research and application.

evidence.evidence_text: Foundation models possess a latent ability to adaptively gather information in interactive environments, both text-based and embodied, opening exciting avenues for research and application.
evidence.limitations: Performance decreases as environmental complexity increases.
evidence.exact_quote: We introduce a framework for evaluating how effectively foundation models can explore new interactive environments and predict hidden reward functions. Our analysis identifies distinct challenges in generating and executing strategic exploratory actions, offering potential solutions.

evidence.evidence_text: Foundation models possess a latent ability to adaptively gather information in interactive environments, both text-based and embodied.
evidence.limitations: Performance decreases as environmental complexity increases.
evidence.exact_quote: We introduce a framework for evaluating how effectively foundation models can explore new interactive environments and predict hidden reward functions. Our analysis identifies distinct challenges in generating and executing strategic exploratory actions, offering potential solutions.

evidence.evidence_text: Foundation models have been used to build agents that play games, which often involves some form of exploration.
evidence.exact_quote: Foundation models have also been used to build agents that play games (e.g., Wang et al., 2023a;b; Feng et al., 2023; Tan et al., 2024), which often involves some form of exploration.

evidence.evidence_text: Foundation models can effectively navigate, adapt, and reason in text-based scenarios that require sequential decision-making and strategic exploration.
evidence.exact_quote: Our experiments with Gemini 1.5 (Reid et al., 2024) reveal significant exploratory capabilities, effective navigation of complex abstract problem spaces, the discovery of novel solutions, and the achievement of predefined objectives with minimal guidance.

evidence.evidence_text: Foundation models possess a latent ability to adaptively gather information in interactive environments, both text-based and embodied.
evidence.limitations: Performance decreases as environmental complexity increases.
evidence.exact_quote: We introduce a framework for evaluating how effectively foundation models can explore new interactive environments and predict hidden reward functions. Our analysis identifies distinct challenges in generating and executing strategic exploratory actions, offering potential solutions.

evidence.evidence_text: Performance tends to decrease as environmental complexity increases.
evidence.location: Section 4.1: EFFECT OF ENVIRONMENTAL COMPLEXITY ON EXPLORATION
evidence.exact_quote: We first examine the effect of varying the amount and type of environmental complexity on strategic exploration and performance. We evaluate the 2 Gemini models’ performance in both single-feature and conjunction tasks. We benchmark against an optimal baseline (upper bound) and random baselines with and without replacement (lower bounds assuming perfect memory and no memory, respectively), and evaluated the optimal and random policies on 1000 episodes and the Gemini models on 200 episodes.

evidence.evidence_text: Gemini’s information gathering capability is close to optimal for single-feature-based rewards.
evidence.location: Section 4.1: EFFECT OF ENVIRONMENTAL COMPLEXITY ON EXPLORATION
evidence.exact_quote: For single-feature-based rewards, we find that smaller models curiously perform better; for conjunction-based rewards, incorporating self-correction into the model improves performance.

evidence.evidence_text: Performance is comparable in both text and 3D embodied environments.
evidence.limitations: Performance is comparable in both text and 3D embodied environments, although imperfect visual object recognition reduces its accuracy in drawing conclusions from gathered information in the 3D embodied case.
evidence.location: Section 4.1: EFFECT OF ENVIRONMENTAL COMPLEXITY ON EXPLORATION
evidence.exact_quote: Performance is comparable in both text and 3D embodied environments, although imperfect visual object recognition reduces its accuracy in drawing conclusions from gathered information in the 3D embodied case.

evidence.evidence_text: Incorporating self-correction into the model improves performance for conjunction-based rewards.
evidence.location: Section 4.2: EFFECTS OF PROMPTING AND CONTEXT LENGTH
evidence.exact_quote: For conjunction tasks, self-correction appears more effective in more complex tasks, either performing comparably, or slightly outperforming the base model.

evidence.evidence_text: The hit in performance is due partly to the model translating task description to a policy and partly to the model’s effectiveness in using its in-context memory.
evidence.location: Section 4.1: EFFECT OF ENVIRONMENTAL COMPLEXITY ON EXPLORATION
evidence.exact_quote: The hit in performance is due partly to the model translating task description to a policy and partly to the model’s effectiveness in using its in-context memory.

evidence.evidence_text: The directed exploration capabilities of foundation models robustly generalize from text-based environments to embodied 3D environments.
evidence.exact_quote: The directed exploration capabilities of foundation models robustly generalize from text-based environments to embodied 3D environments, though overall accuracy of the system is somewhat reduced by imperfect performance of the VLM’s object and action recognition in videos.

evidence.evidence_text: The challenges of multi-modal reasoning from realistic simulated video could be addressed by focusing on the vision and action recognition capabilities of foundation models separately from their reasoning capabilities.
evidence.exact_quote: The challenges of multi-modal reasoning from realistic simulated video could be addressed by focusing on the vision and action recognition capabilities of foundation models separately from their reasoning capabilities.

evidence.evidence_text: The paper makes three key contributions.
evidence.exact_quote: This work makes three key contributions: - Framework development: We propose a novel framework for evaluating the directed exploration capabilities of LLMs and VLMs in interactive environments, outlining methodologies for assessment in the zero-shot setting, without the need for fine-tuning or other post-training modifications. - Empirical analysis: We conduct extensive experiments across various environments and tasks, and across several model variants and prompting strategies, to analyze the exploration performance and behaviors of LLMs and VLMs in interactive settings. - Insights and implications: We provide a detailed discussion on the implications of our findings for future research in foundation models and the development of autonomous intelligent agents.

conclusion.key_limitations: Performance decreases as environmental complexity increases

claim.text: Foundation models have revolutionized natural language processing (NLP) and multi-modal dialogue, achieving remarkable proficiency in understanding and generating human-like text.
claim.type: Statement about the impact of foundation models
claim.exact_quote: Foundation models have revolutionized natural language processing (NLP) and multi-modal dialogue, achieving remarkable proficiency in understanding and generating human-like text.

claim.text: Foundation models have been used to build agents that play games, which often involves some form of exploration.
claim.type: Statement about the use of foundation models in games
claim.exact_quote: Foundation models have also been used to build agents that play games (e.g., Wang et al., 2023a;b; Feng et al., 2023; Tan et al., 2024), which often involves some form of exploration.

claim.text: Foundation models can effectively navigate, adapt, and reason in text-based scenarios that require sequential decision-making and strategic exploration.
claim.type: Claim about the capabilities of foundation models
claim.exact_quote: Our experiments with Gemini 1.5 (Reid et al., 2024) reveal significant exploratory capabilities, effective navigation of complex abstract problem spaces, the discovery of novel solutions, and the achievement of predefined objectives with minimal guidance.

claim.text: Foundation models possess a latent ability to adaptively gather information in interactive environments, both text-based and embodied.
claim.type: Claim about the adaptability of foundation models
claim.exact_quote: These findings suggest that foundation models possess a latent ability to adaptively gather information in interactive environments, both text-based and embodied, opening exciting avenues for research and application.

conclusion.key_limitations: Performance decreases as environmental complexity increases

claim.text: Performance tends to decrease as environmental complexity increases.
claim.type: Claim about the effect of environmental complexity on performance
claim.exact_quote: While performance tends to decrease as environmental complexity increases, such as more complex reward functions or when moving to 3D environments that require visual understanding, exploration efficiency significantly outperforms random baselines.

claim.text: Gemini’s information gathering capability is close to optimal for single-feature-based rewards.
claim.type: Claim about Gemini's performance in single-feature tasks
claim.exact_quote: For single-feature-based rewards, we find that smaller models curiously perform better; for conjunction-based rewards, incorporating self-correction into the model improves performance.

claim.text: Performance is comparable in both text and 3D embodied environments.
claim.type: Claim about the generalizability of performance across environments
claim.exact_quote: Performance is comparable in both text and 3D embodied environments, although imperfect visual object recognition reduces its accuracy in drawing conclusions from gathered information in the 3D embodied case.

claim.text: Incorporating self-correction into the model improves performance for conjunction-based rewards.
claim.type: Claim about the impact of self-correction on performance
claim.exact_quote: For conjunction-based rewards, incorporating self-correction into the model improves performance.

claim.text: The hit in performance is due partly to the model translating task description to a policy and partly to the model’s effectiveness in using its in-context memory.
claim.type: Claim about the reasons for suboptimal performance
claim.exact_quote: The hit in performance is due partly to the model translating task description to a policy and partly to the model’s effectiveness in using its in-context memory.

claim.text: The directed exploration capabilities of foundation models robustly generalize from text-based environments to embodied 3D environments.
claim.type: Claim about the generalization of exploration capabilities
claim.exact_quote: The strong performance of foundation models in our exploration tasks motivates further research with more complex environments and methods for improving visual perception.

claim.text: The challenges of multi-modal reasoning from realistic simulated video could be addressed by focusing on the vision and action recognition capabilities of foundation models separately from their reasoning capabilities.
claim.type: Claim about the potential solutions for improving performance
claim.exact_quote: This indicates that the challenges of multi-modal reasoning from realistic simulated video could be addressed by focusing on the vision and action recognition capabilities of foundation models separately from their reasoning capabilities.

claim.text: The paper makes three key contributions.
claim.type: Claim about the contributions of the paper
claim.exact_quote: This work makes three key contributions: - Framework development: We propose a novel framework for evaluating the directed exploration capabilities of LLMs and VLMs in interactive environments, outlining methodologies for assessment in the zero-shot setting, without the need for fine-tuning or other post-training modifications.
